Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Optimization Models and Approximation Algorithms for Network Vulnerability and Adaptability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Complex network systems are extremely vulnerable. This vulnerability may be propagated, leading to a much more devastating consequence. Furthermore, several network algorithms must be adaptable to changes in order to maintain their functions. In the presence of uncertainty, network vulnerability and adaptability are the two major aspects that must be deeply investigated.

This proposal is using optimization theory and approximation techniques to address the following fundamental questions: How do we quantitatively measure the vulnerability degree of the network? How is the vulnerability propagated? What are the quantitative benefits of using adaptive solutions vs. re-computing it from scratch? What techniques can we use for adaptive solutions in order to theoretically bound their performance? The proposal provides several new theoretical frameworks and approximation techniques to characterize the network vulnerability and adaptability, which brings the understanding of network vulnerability and adaptability to the next level.

This research can potentially impact nearly all applications that benefit from networks such as the Internet, critical network infrastructures, and transportation networks where vulnerability and adaptability are important characteristics. In addition to its obvious impact on networks, the project crosses several research areas such as graph theory, approximation algorithms, combinatorial optimization, and computational complexity, thus it has a profound impact on the theory of optimization and approximation, especially the adaptive approximation techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Complex network systems are often greatly affected by several uncertain factors, including external natural or man-made interferences (e.g., severe weather, enemy attacks, malicious attacks.) In the presence of uncertainty, network vulnerability and adaptability are the two major aspects that must be deeply investigated in order to maintain the full functionality of a system.

Many complex systems are extremely vulnerable to attacks, that is, the failure of a few key nodes that play a vital role in maintaining the network’s connectivity can break down their operation. In addition, this vulnerability may be propagated, leading to a much more devastating consequence. Furthermore, several network algorithms must be adaptable to changes in order to maintain their functions. For example, changes in a network topology may cause the reconfiguration of any routing algorithm since the previous routing path may no longer be available. A natural attempt for this adaption would be to update the routing path based on the previous path since a portion of this path can be reused. The solution which is updated from the previous one is called an adaptive solution.

Despite many existing works on network vulnerability and adaptability, several fundamental questions about network vulnerability and adaptability remain unexplored. This project has addressed the following fundamental questions: 1) What are the key nodes that play a vital role in maintaining the network’s functionality? 2) How is the vulnerability cascaded? 3) What are the quantitative benefits of using adaptive solutions vs. re-computing it from scratch? What techniques can we use for adaptive solutions in order to theoretically bound their performance?

The project has resulted in 3 edited books, 6 book chapters, 27 journal articles, and 38 peer reviewed conference papers witht tthe following contribution.

Intellectual Merits.  1. Provided a comprehensive algorithmic tools to quantitatively assess the network vulnerability and correctly identify the key nodes in the network with uncertainty, taking into account the cascading failures with different time scale in the systems; (2) Provided theoretical frameworks to characterize the network interdependency through novel approaches of using network modules in complex systems to investigate how the vulnerability propagates, thus further exploit the network vulnerability. One major finding is that community structure is indeed quite vulnerable, not very robust as belief. (3) Designed new approximation techniques to obtain adaptive solutions with a provable performance bound, which will advance the theory of optimization and approximation. The solutions developed by this project provides solid and rigorous analyses of network vulnerability and adaptability, which brings the understanding of network vulnerability and adaptability to the next level.

Broader Impacts. This project has the potential to impact nearly all applications that benefit from networks such as the Internet, the critical network infrastructures, and transportation where vulnerability and adaptability are important characteristics. The solutions are also investigated on complex networks with the scale free property, thus the results will advance the state of knowledge of the social network theory by providing new mathematical models and techniques in analyzing structural features of dynamic networks. The study also finds applications in several other fields, such as network immunization, offering control of epidemic outbreaks and containment of viruses. It can be used in designing strategies for modeling communication breakdowns in communication networks and to destroy, i.e. arrest, a small number of key individuals in an adversarial social network (e.g. terrorist networks) in order to maximally disrupt the networks ability to deploy a coordinated attack. In addition to its obvious impact on networks, the project crosses several research areas such as graph theory, approximation algorithms, combinatorial optimization, and computational complexity, thus it has a profound impact on the theory of optimization and approximation algorithms.

The project helped training 8 Ph.D students who has already graduated, and 2 PhD students are in their final years. The PI has developed several new courses both for undergraduate and graduate level based on the outcomes of this project. Furthermore, the PI has recruited three female Ph.D. students working on this projects, as well as hosting 10th grades students and undergrad female students during the summers for the outreach program.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.


Last Modified: 10/28/2016
Modified by: My T Thai
